subject: RE: [junit] problem with assert equals
msgSnippet: So said  Durham David Cntr 805CSS/SCBE  on  2002-11-14 ... mil.usaf.rad.course.tests.CourseFactoryTest.testCreateSection(Unknown ... section2.getName()); ...
messageBody:
So said Durham David Cntr 805CSS/SCBE on 2002-11-14

>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
>> Sent: Thursday, November 14, 2002 10:53 AM
>> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>> Subject: Re: [junit] problem with assert equals
>>
>>
>> So said Durham David Cntr 805CSS/SCBE on 2002-11-14
>>
>> >I am making an assertion in a test script and it is throwing
>> an error.
>> I
>> >know that the arguments that I am passing into the assertion
>> are valid
>> >String objects.
>> >
>> >Here's the error:
>> >
>> > Caused an ERROR
>> >junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/l
>> ang/String
>> ;)V
>> > at
>>
mil.usaf.rad.course.tests.CourseFactoryTest.testCreateSection(Unknown
>> >Source)
>> > at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
>> > at
>> >sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAcces
>> sorImpl.ja
>> va:39)
>> > at
>> >sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMet
>> hodAccesso
>> rImpl.java:25)
>> > at
>> org.netbeans.core.execution.RunClassThread.run(RunClassThread.
>> java:119)
>> >
>> >
>> >Here's the code:
>> >
>> > public void testCreateSection() throws Exception {
>> > Section section = CourseFactory.newSection();
>> > section.setCourse(course);
>> > section.setName("section");
>> > section.setAccountRequired(false);
>> > section.save();
>> >
>> > Section section2 =
>> >CourseFactory.getSection(section.getSectionID());
>> >
>> > //System.err.println("section2 name: " +
section2.getName());
>> > //System.err.println("section name: " + section.getName());
>> >>> assertEquals(section.getName(), section2.getName()); //
>> throws
>> >the error
>> > assertEquals(section.getCourse(), section2.getCourse());
//
>> if I
>> >comment the line above, then this line will run just fine.
>> > assertEquals(section.getAccountRequired(),
>> >section2.getAccountRequired());
>> > }
>> >
>> >
>> >If I uncomment the System.err lines then I see that both of these
>> objects
>> >have the name "section" which is what I want, but for some reason
the
>> call
>> >to assertEquals will throw the error above.
>> >
>> >Does anyone know what would or could be causing this?
>>
>> I don't, but I have another suggestion once you get past that
problem:
>> consider implementing equals() and hashCode() on "Section" and just
>> checking
>>
>> assertEquals(section, section2);
>>
>> The tests become less brittle and easier to read. :)
>>
>
>
>That's a good point, but I also want to check to see if the references
are
>to the exact same object otherwise the factory is not
>doing what it is supposed to do. It does get worse as more methods
are
>added to the testing so I've been using reflection to loop through
them.
>
>Got any ideas on this?

Well, there's assertSame() to check whether the factory is providing
the same object.

If your goal is to run the same tests for multiple factory methods,
then you could use a pattern similar to JUnit's TestCase class itself.
Create an instance of the factory method, then use the abstract test
case pattern to write unifying tests.

Here is an example:

MyFactory {
factoryMethod1() {...}
factoryMethod2() {...}
}

abstract FactoryCreatesSameObjectTestCase extends TestCase {
abstract makeFactory() {...}
testSameObject() {
MyFactory factory = makeFactory();
assertSame(factory.makeObject(), factory.makeObject());
}
}

FactoryMethodTestCase extends FactoryCreatesSameObjectTestCase {
suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.addTest(new FactoryMethodTestCase() {
makeFactory() {
return new Factory("factoryMethod1");
}
});
suite.addTest(new FactoryMethodTestCase() {
makeFactory() {
return new Factory("factoryMethod2");
}
});
return suite;
}
}

You can then refactor the "addTest" calls to loop over a list of
factory method names. Then refactor the names out to a properties file.

The abstract test case ensures that the same "testSameObject" test is
executed for all the factory methods. You can supplement these tests
with additional, factory-method-specific tests, as needed.

Does that help?
